narrative: Let me share a story from when I was twenty-two years old, just fresh out of college. I was staying in a small town about five miles from here. I had just started my first job at a local bookstore. It was a quiet afternoon, and I was alone in the store. My grandpa, who had been bedridden for almost a year, was at home with my sister. She had to care for him daily, as he couldn't move around on his own. There were only two of us siblings, my sister and me. My parents had gone out of town for the weekend. As I was shelving books, I suddenly heard a voice inside my head. It said, "If you go to the old church down the street and light a candle for your grandpa, he will get better." I looked around the bookstore, but no one was there. I continued with my work, trying to ignore the voice. It spoke to me again, repeating the same message. I looked around once more, but still found no one. I decided to take a break and walk to the church. I was only a short distance away, maybe a quarter-mile. As I approached the church, I hesitated for a moment. I was not a particularly religious person. I remembered my grandma always saying that prayers from a sincere heart could bring miracles. On the other hand, she also said that prayers without faith were useless. I admitted to myself that I was far from being a saint. I had my share of mistakes and misdeeds. I thought about my grandpa and how much he meant to our family. Finally, I went inside the church and found a candle. I knelt down in front of the altar. I said, "God, I don't know how to pray properly. But I am asking you with all my heart to heal my grandpa. Please help him regain his strength and guide us in taking care of him." After saying my prayer, I returned to the bookstore. I resumed my work, shelving books. Suddenly, I felt a strong urge to go home. It was as if something was pulling me towards the house. I didn't hear any voice this time. It was just an overwhelming feeling that I needed to go. I locked up the store and rushed home. To my surprise, I found my grandpa sitting in the living room, talking to my sister. He hadn't been able to leave his bed for months without assistance. My sister told me that he had suddenly felt a surge of energy and was able to stand up and walk. That day marked the beginning of his recovery. He gradually regained his strength and independence. It was a turning point in our lives. We became more grateful for the time we had together. I often thought back to that day in the church. I wondered if my prayer had anything to do with my grandpa's recovery. I couldn't be sure, but it definitely changed my perspective on faith and the power of prayer. My grandpa lived for many more years after that incident. He celebrated his ninetieth birthday surrounded by family and friends. We cherished every moment we had with him. That experience happened almost twenty years ago. It remains a vivid memory in my mind. My grandpa passed away a few years later, but his spirit lives on in our hearts. Sometimes, when I'm feeling lost or uncertain, I think back to that day. I remember the power of faith and the miracles it can bring. And I am reminded that we are never truly alone, even when it seems like we are.

One night while stacking shelves at work I hear a voice in my mind - telling me to go to the Church nearby, and light a candle: this would help my grandpa get better. 
I had reservations as I was far from religious but I went to the Church about a quarter mile away, found, and lit a candle. I suddenly felt an inescapable urge to go home, which I gave in to only to see Grandpa, who had been bedridden remember, up and walking. He'd, that night, felt a rush of energy and every night after got better and better, living for many many years afterwards. He made it to ninety. I still think back to that night very often, and wonder whether my act of lighting that candle and giving a prayer really made a difference or not. Either way it changed my whole outlook on faith.

The man went to the church to pray and light the candle. The man went back to the bookstore to work. The man went back home to find his grandpa better. The man's sister told him he had recovered. The grandpa lived longer but eventually died.
recalls.5e4464d23e28c82e888fa598: I was 22 just out of college and i started working with my grandad at our bookstore, he quickly became very ill and bedridden  one day when working I heard a voice whisper and say that if I went to the local church and lit a candle my grandad would be fine, although no one was around when I looked. I remembered my grandma saying that prayers made with good hearts could create miracles, I was no saint but what harm could it do. So I went to the church with a candle, praying that he was alright. I got the feeling to suddenly go home, Grandad was out of bed looking much better. He ended up living many years more and celebrating his 90th birthday, the whole experience was 20 years ago but gave me a much different perspective on religion and prayer.
recalls.62fba19b31689f425e047e01: This Young Lady bookstore keeper , her grandpa's got seriously ill. And, while she was at the her bookstore, arranging the shelves'.... etc. She suddenly heard a voice urging her to go to Church to make some prayer's. The inner voice was telling her that if she done so her Grandpa's would certainly become well. She followed the instructions accordingly and done so. Moreover, after she prayed gpt back to her store and then she had that strong urge and emotions telling her to head back home now!! She went back home she found her grandpa's sitting with her sisiter having a chin-wag she become well and fit like a horse. From, that day forward she knew the importance of faith, the whole family become more religious, grateful to life and cherished every moment!! Finally, her grandpa's fully recovered and lived on many years full of health and joy.
recalls.5841a2d39d65770001cebfa1:
Working in a bookshop after college.
My sister at home caring for my bedridden grandpa. It is just me and my sister.
I hear a voice urging me to go to the church and light a candle and my Grandpa will recover.  I go to the Church and even though I'm not religious and have made many mistakes in my life I light a candle and say a prayer. My Grandmother said a prayer from a genuine heart can make miracles bit also that a prayer without faith was meaningless. I then return to the shop. I feel an urge to go home. When I get there my Grandpa is sat in the living room. My sister said he felt a surge of energy which helped to get him out of bed. I wondered if it was the lighting of the candle. My Grandpa lived to be 90 and celebrated his birthday  surrounded by family and friends and I recall that day 20 years ago which helped me cherish the time I had with my family.

1. Given: "Let me share a story. I was twenty-two years old, fresh out of college."
2. Given: "I was staying in a small town about five miles from here."
3. Given: "I had just started my first job at a local bookstore."
4. Given: "It was a quiet afternoon, and I was alone in the store."
5. Given: "My grandpa, who had been bedridden for almost a year, was at home with my sister."
6. Given: "She had to care for him daily, as he couldn't move around on his own."
7. Given: "There were only two of us siblings, my sister and me."
8. Given: "My parents had gone out of town for the weekend."
9. Given: "As I was shelving books, I suddenly heard a voice inside my head."
10. Given: "It said, "If you go to the old church down the street and light a candle for your grandpa, he will get better.""
11. Given: "I looked around the bookstore, but no one was there."
12. Given: "I continued with my work, trying to ignore the voice."
13. Given: "It spoke to me again, repeating the same message."
14. Given: "I looked around once more, but still found no one."
15. Given: "I decided to take a break and walk to the church."
16. Given: "I was only a short distance away, maybe a quarter-mile."
17. Given: "As I approached the church, I hesitated for a moment."
18. Given: "I was not a religious person."
19. Given: "I remembered my grandma always saying that prayers from a sincere heart could bring miracles."
20. Given: "On the other hand, she also said that prayers without faith were useless."
21. Given: "I admitted to myself that I was far from being a saint."
22. Given: "I had my share of mistakes and misdeeds."
23. Given: "I thought about my grandpa and how much he meant to our family."
24. Given: "Finally, I went inside the church and found a candle."
25. Given: "I knelt down in front of the altar."
26. Given: "I said, "God, I don't know how to pray properly."
27. Given: "But I am asking you with all my heart to heal my grandpa."
28. Given: "Please help him regain his strength and guide us in taking care of him.""
29. Given: "After saying a prayer, I returned to the bookstore."
30. Given: "I resumed my work, shelving books."
31. Given: "Suddenly, I felt a strong urge to go home."
32. Given: "It was as if something was pulling me towards the house."
33. Given: "I didn't hear any voice this time."
34. Given: "It was just an overwhelming feeling that I needed to go home."
35. Given: "I locked up the store and rushed home."
36. Given: "To my surprise, I found my grandpa sitting in the living room, talking to my sister."
37. Given: "He hadn't been able to leave his bed for months without assistance."
38. Given: "My sister told me that he had suddenly felt a surge of energy and was able to stand up and walk."
39. Given: "That day started the beginning of his recovery."
40. Given: "He gradually regained his strength and independence."
41. Given: "It was a turning point in our lives."
42. Given: "We became more grateful for the time we had together."
43. Given: "I often thought back to that day in the church."
44. Given: "I wondered if my prayer had anything to do with my grandpa's recovery."
45. Given: "I couldn't be sure, but it definitely changed my perspective on faith and the power of prayer."
46. Given: "My grandpa lived for many more years after that incident."
47. Given: "He celebrated his ninetieth birthday surrounded by family and friends."
48. Given: "We cherished every moment we had with him."
49. Given: "That experience happened almost twenty years ago."
50. Given: "It remains a vivid memory in my mind."
51. Given: "My grandpa passed away a few years later, but his spirit lives on in our hearts."
52. Given: "Sometimes, when I'm feeling lost or uncertain, I think back to that day."
53. Given: "I remember the power of faith and the miracles it can bring."
54. Given: "And I am reminded that we are never truly alone, even when it seems like we are."

recalls segmented.5f305d059a58b14b23eeccb8:
1. A 22yr old girl fresh out of college worked in her family's bookstore.
2. She had 1 sister & a grandpa who was bedridden for months.
3. Her parents were out of town for the weekend.
4. Her sister was the only one home with grandpa while the girl worked at the bookstore.
5. Suddenly she heard a voice in her head while shelving books.
6. That she must go to the church down the road & light a candle and say a prayer for her grandpa to get well.
7. She ended up closing the store.
8. She went to the church & did just that.
9. After returning to the bookstore she felt an urge to go home.
10. She found her grandpa full of energy & well.
11. Her sister told her that her grandpa suddenly got up & felt better.
12. He got better since that day & lived to an old age.
13. When times are tough even though its been over 20yrs ago now the girl still thinks of that moment.
recalls segmented.6032903277ccb729ab92972d:
1. It was a story about a man
2. who after college went to work in a bookstore.
3. He lived with his sister, grandfather and parents.
4. One weekend when his parents were away,
5. he was working his regular shift at the bookstore
6. when he heard a voice tell him to light a candle
7. and it would heal his sickely grandfather who was bedridden.
8. After his shift he left the bookstore
9. and went to the church
10. where he lit a candle
11. and prayed.
12. Shortly after he got a phone call from his sister
13. that their grandfather had gotten out of bed
14. and was energetic.
15. Over the months the grandfather got better
16. and lived to be over 90 years old before he passed away.
17. The man often wonders if his prayer was the cause
18. that healed his grandfather of sickness.
recalls segmented.61109e59e55dc2f6bf8b2ea9:
1. A person was reflecting on a time when they were working in a bookstore after college
2. and got the feeling to go pray
3. and light a candle for their grandpa in a nearby church
4. because he was bedridden
5. and needed to be taken care of by the person's sister.
6. The person wasn't very religious
7. but still went to pray anyway
8. then went back to work.
9. They then got a feeling to go home
10. and when they did they saw their grandpa out if bed
11. and in the living room.
12. He then started to get better and better
13. and regain his strength.
14. He lived for a few more years
15. and celebrated his 90th birthday with family and friends.

17. and valued the power of faith and prayer more after that experience.
recalls segmented.5ea5da26b447b8458c6270e6:
1. Twenty-two years old, fresh out of college.
2. Started a new job at a bookstore.
3. Sister was looking after grandpa.
4. I heard a voice which said to go the the church and light a candle and pray for him.
5. I then heard it again.
6. I went at lunch, it was only a short walk, about quarter of a mile.
7. I went inside the church and lit a candle.
8. I prayed to God, please help my grandpa, I am asking with all my heart please help him get better.
9. I returned to work.
10. I got an overwhelming feeling to go home.
11. It wasn't a voice this time.
12. Just an overwhelming feeling urging me to go.
13. I locked up the store and went home.
14. To my surprise, there was my grandpa in the living room, sitting on a chair talking to my sister.
15. He hadn't been out of bed for months.
16. From that day my grandpa continued his recovery.
17. He lived many more years.
18. We cherished that time we had together.
19. I often think back to that day and think did God really hear me and help.
20. It definitely changed my perspective on faith and god.
21. My grandpa celebrated his 90th birthday surrounded by friends and family.
22. He lived a few more years after that.
23. I often think back about him and that time we had together.
24. I often think about that day in church.
recalls segmented.5f7f239e9b204e05b6c36538:
1. I want to share with a story of when I was twenty two back in college.
2. At home we lived with my grandpa who was now bedridden for months.
3. There was just two siblings, me and my sister.
4. Our parents were away on weekend and my sister was the one taking care of him.
5. One day when I was at store packing book on shelves, I heard a voice saying " if you go to the church and light a candle for your grandpa, he will get better".
6. I turned around to see who was there but there was no one.
7. I continued packing the books on the shelves till I heard the voice again.
8. I turned around again but still there was no one.
9. I then left the store and made my way to the church.
10. About a quarter mile away, I stopped and pondered.
11. I was not a religious person but my grandmother used to say prayer from a sincere heart can bring miracles, but she said prayer without faith is useless.
12. Finally I went inside and lit the candle and prayed.
13. I went back to the store and had a strong urge to go back home.
14. There no voices this time, just an overwhelming feeling.
15. I immediately locked up the store and went home.
16. I walked in to find my grandpa sitting in the dining room with my sister.

recalls segmented.5de16fd00e58661bb3519db8:
1. Let me share a story.
2. I was twenty-two years old, fresh out of college.
3. I was staying in a small town about five miles from here.
4. I had just started my first job at a local bookstore.
5. It was a quiet afternoon, and I was alone in the store.
6. My grandpa, who had been bedridden for almost a year, was at home with my sister.
7. She had to care for him daily, as he couldn't move around on his own.
8. There were only two of us siblings, my sister and me.
9. My parents had gone out of town for the weekend.
10. As I was shelving books, I suddenly heard a voice inside my head.
11. It said, "If you go to the old church down the street and light a candle for your grandpa, he will get better."
12. I looked around the bookstore, but no one was there.
13. I continued with my work, trying to ignore the voice.
14. It spoke to me again, repeating the same message.
15. I looked around once more, but still found no one.
16. I decided to take a break and walk to the church.
17. I was only a short distance away, maybe a quarter-mile.
18. As I approached the church, I hesitated for a moment.
19. I was not a religious person.
20. I remembered my grandma always saying that prayers from a sincere heart could bring miracles.
21. On the other hand, she also said that prayers without faith were useless.
22. I admitted to myself that I was far from being a saint.
23. I had my share of mistakes and misdeeds.
24. I thought about my grandpa and how much he meant to our family.
25. Finally, I went inside the church and found a candle.
26. I knelt down in front of the altar.
27. I said, "God, I don't know how to pray properly. But I am asking you with all my heart to heal my grandpa. Please help him regain his strength and guide us in taking care of him."
28. After saying a prayer, I returned to the bookstore.
29. I resumed my work, shelving books.
30. Suddenly, I felt a strong urge to go home.
31. It was as if something was pulling me towards the house.
32. I didn't hear any voice this time.
33. It was just an overwhelming feeling that I needed to go home.
34. I locked up the store and rushed home.
35. To my surprise, I found my grandpa sitting in the living room, talking to my sister.
36. He hadn't been able to leave his bed for months without assistance.
37. My sister told me that he had suddenly felt a surge of energy and was able to stand up and walk.
38. That day started the beginning of his recovery.
39. He gradually regained his strength and independence.
40. It was a turning point in our lives.
41. We became more grateful for the time we had together.
42. I often thought back to that day in the church.
43. I wondered if my prayer had anything to do with my grandpa's recovery.
44. I couldn't be sure, but it definitely changed my perspective on faith and the power of prayer.
45. My grandpa lived for many more years after that incident.
46. He celebrated his ninetieth birthday surrounded by family and friends.
47. We cherished every moment we had with him.
48. That experience happened almost twenty years ago.
49. It remains a vivid memory in my mind.
50. My grandpa passed away a few years later, but his spirit lives on in our hearts.
51. Sometimes, when I'm feeling lost or uncertain, I think back to that day.
52. I remember the power of faith and the miracles it can bring.
53. And I am reminded that we are never truly alone, even when it seems like we are.
